articles.headline: Ready to Fight Gay Marriage at Court Door
articles.snippet: Brian S. Brown has become the nation’s leading opponent of gay marriage. Now, his views are set for the ultimate American test: a Supreme Court hearing.
articles.abstract: Brian S. Brown has become the nation’s leading opponent of gay marriage. Now, his views are set for the ultimate American test: a Supreme Court hearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As gay couples fight for the right to wed, a little-known but determined force is working to stop them: Brian S. Brown, a 39-year-old father of eight who has raised millions of dollars from religious conservatives — especially his fellow Roman Catholics — to become the nation’s leading opponent of same-sex marriage.

articles.headline: However Justices Rule, Issues Remain
articles.snippet: A victory for gay rights in either of two monumental cases before the Supreme Court this week will not settle the financial and legal issues that same-sex couples face.
articles.abstract: A victory for gay rights in either of two monumental cases before the Supreme Court this week will not settle the financial and legal issues that same-sex couples face.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the Supreme Court strikes down the law that defines marriage as between one man and one woman, same-sex couples across the country will undoubtedly gain access to a broad range of federal benefits.

articles.headline: Digitally Aided Education, Using the Students’ Own Electronic Gear
articles.snippet: In a growing trend, school districts pressed for money are allowing students to bring their phones, laptop computers or tablets to be used in the classroom.
articles.abstract: In a growing trend, school districts pressed for money are allowing students to bring their phones, laptop computers or tablets to be used in the classroom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Educators and policy makers continue to debate whether computers are a good teaching tool. But a growing number of schools are adopting a new, even more controversial approach: asking students to bring their own smartphones, tablets, laptops and even their video game players to class.

articles.headline: Wealthy Russians Ensnared as Cyprus Crisis Deepens
articles.snippet: About 25 percent of Russian foreign direct investment moves through Cyprus, according to an estimate, often in a way meant to lubricate Russia’s economy.
articles.abstract: About 25 percent of Russian foreign direct investment moves through Cyprus, according to an estimate, often in a way meant to lubricate Russia’s economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Two decades ago, Dmitry E. Rybolovlev was a small-town hustler hoping to strike it rich amid the collapse of the Soviet Union. Today, he is one of the wealthiest men in the world, with a penthouse in Monaco, a yacht named “My Anna” worth more than $100 million, and two of the most expensive private residences in the United States.

articles.headline: Teeing Off at Edge of the Arctic? A Chinese Plan Baffles Iceland
articles.snippet: An Icelandic frontier village, eyed by a Chinese billionaire for a golf resort, is the setting for a drama involving intrigue, millions of dollars and a swarm of conspiracy theories.
articles.abstract: An Icelandic frontier village, eyed by a Chinese billionaire for a golf resort, is the setting for a drama involving intrigue, millions of dollars and a swarm of conspiracy theories.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRIMSSTADIR, Iceland — Struggling to stand upright against a howling wind, Bragi Benediktsson looked out over his family’s land — a barren expanse of snow and ice that a Chinese billionaire wants to turn into a golf course — and laughed. “Golf here is difficult,” said Mr. Benediktsson, a 75-year-old sheep farmer.

articles.headline: The Attachment That Still Makes Noise
articles.snippet: The stapler remains the one office tool that gives the satisfying click of a job that’s done.
articles.abstract: The stapler remains the one office tool that gives the satisfying click of a job that’s done.
articles.lead_paragraph: DO you have a stapler?

articles.headline: Mortgages’ Future Looks Too Much Like the Past
articles.snippet: An alternative under discussion to replace Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the big mortgage guarantors, sounds an awful lot like the status quo, with taxpayers as the backstop.
articles.abstract: An alternative under discussion to replace Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the big mortgage guarantors, sounds an awful lot like the status quo, with taxpayers as the backstop.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN a perfect world, policy makers, legislators and concerned Americans would have spent the last few years conducting an honest dialogue about two important issues: how to resolve Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-owned mortgage finance giants, and how to create a housing finance system that would serve borrowers without imperiling taxpayers.

articles.headline: Tackling Concerns of Independent Workers
articles.snippet: The Freelancers Union, one of the nation’s fastest-growing labor organizations, seeks to make health insurance and other benefits more affordable for independent workers.
articles.abstract: The Freelancers Union, one of the nation’s fastest-growing labor organizations, seeks to make health insurance and other benefits more affordable for independent workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOON after landing a job at a Manhattan law firm nearly 20 years ago, Sara Horowitz was shocked to discover that it planned to treat her not as an employee, but as an independent contractor.

articles.headline: Russian Ties Put Cyprus Banking Crisis on East-West Fault Line
articles.snippet: With Cyprus’s role as a provider of financial services for Russians, what began as another episode in a familiar narrative has escalated into a drama with geopolitical implications.
articles.abstract: With Cyprus’s role as a provider of financial services for Russians, what began as another episode in a familiar narrative has escalated into a drama with geopolitical implications.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIMASSOL, Cyprus — Andreas Marangos, a Porsche-driving lawyer here, had just woken up when he heard the news that threatened to destroy his and Cyprus’s most lucrative business: setting up shell companies and providing financial services for wealthy Russians.

articles.headline: Jammed in Roman Caves, Ducking Syria’s War
articles.snippet: In Syria, the caves of bygone times have become essential once more, restored to modern use because their thick walls offer a chance of survival to a population under fire.
articles.abstract: In Syria, the caves of bygone times have become essential once more, restored to modern use because their thick walls offer a chance of survival to a population under fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: SARJAH, Syria — Abdulkader Darwish did not go far after a Syrian military aircraft dropped a bomb near his house last year, prompting him to gather his family and flee. He ventured with a shovel into the local olive groves. There he dug through the sealed entrance to an abandoned Roman cave.

articles.headline: Shadow of Roe v. Wade Looms Over Ruling on Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: Even supporters of abortion rights believe the 1973 Supreme Court ruling went too far, too fast, a lesson opponents of same-sex marriage hope the court, hearing two cases, will take to heart.
articles.abstract: Even supporters of abortion rights believe the 1973 Supreme Court ruling went too far, too fast, a lesson opponents of same-sex marriage hope the court, hearing two cases, will take to heart.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court hears a pair of cases on same-sex marriage on Tuesday and Wednesday, the justices will be working in the shadow of a 40-year-old decision on another subject entirely: Roe v. Wade, the 1973 ruling that established a constitutional right to abortion.

articles.headline: Immigrants Held in Solitary Cells, Often for Weeks
articles.snippet: New federal data shows that on any given day, about 300 immigrants are held in solitary confinement at Immigration and Customs Enforcement centers, a practice psychiatrists worry is overly punitive.
articles.abstract: New federal data shows that on any given day, about 300 immigrants are held in solitary confinement at Immigration and Customs Enforcement centers, a practice psychiatrists worry is overly punitive.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On any given day, about 300 immigrants are held in solitary confinement at the 50 largest detention facilities that make up the sprawling patchwork of holding centers nationwide overseen by Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials, according to new federal data.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina and Catherine Rentz

articles.headline: Tennessee Race for Medicaid: Dial Fast and Try, Try Again
articles.snippet: The state opens a health care hot line for a few hours each year for patients who do not qualify for Medicaid. Thousands try, but not many qualify for the limited funds.
articles.abstract: The state opens a health care hot line for a few hours each year for patients who do not qualify for Medicaid. Thousands try, but not many qualify for the limited funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Two nights a year, Tennessee holds a health care lottery of sorts, giving the medically desperate a chance to get help.

articles.headline: In Leak Case, State Secrecy in Plain Sight
articles.snippet: The government is withholding details about Pfc. Bradley Manning’s ostensibly public trial over state secrets.
articles.abstract: The government is withholding details about Pfc. Bradley Manning’s ostensibly public trial over state secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reporters covering the government’s prosecution of Pfc. Bradley Manning, who is being court-martialed for conveying secret information to WikiLeaks, have spent a year trying to pierce the veil of secrecy in what is supposed to be a public proceeding.

articles.headline: Pension Funds Wary as Bankrupt City Goes to Trial
articles.snippet: In Stockton, Calif., bondholders and insurers want the pain of the city’s bankruptcy to be evenly distributed. Calpers, the country’s largest pension system, prefers to protect its retirees.
articles.abstract: In Stockton, Calif., bondholders and insurers want the pain of the city’s bankruptcy to be evenly distributed. Calpers, the country’s largest pension system, prefers to protect its retirees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street is taking America’s biggest pension fund to court this week, for a long-awaited battle over who takes the losses when a city goes bust — workers and retirees, municipal bondholders, or both.

articles.headline: For Homesick Russian Tycoon, Instant of Ruin Came in Court
articles.snippet: It is still unclear how Boris A. Berezovsky died, but what is certain is that a humiliating court ruling last August helped to drive the exiled oligarch into despair.
articles.abstract: It is still unclear how Boris A. Berezovsky died, but what is certain is that a humiliating court ruling last August helped to drive the exiled oligarch into despair.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The moment of ruin for Boris A. Berezovsky, the exiled Russian oligarch who was found dead on Saturday outside London, came not when he fell out with the Kremlin, or when his latest long-term relationship broke up, or even when Russia sentenced him to prison in absentia.

articles.headline: E.U. Officials Agree to a Deal Rescuing Cyprus
articles.snippet: The deal, struck after hours of meetings in Brussels, would drastically reduce the size of the country’s banking sector and scrap the controversial tax on bank deposits.
articles.abstract: The deal, struck after hours of meetings in Brussels, would drastically reduce the size of the country’s banking sector and scrap the controversial tax on bank deposits.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Struggling into the early-morning hours to avoid a collapse of Cyprus’s banking system, European Union leaders on Monday agreed on a bailout package intended to keep Cyprus in the euro zone and rebuild its devastated economy.
articles.byline: By James Kanter, Liz Alderman and Andrew Higgins

articles.headline: 2 Rivals Complicate Deal for Dell
articles.snippet: The private equity giant Blackstone Group and the investor Carl C. Icahn have each separately submitted preliminary takeover proposal for Dell, the embattled computer maker.
articles.abstract: The private equity giant Blackstone Group and the investor Carl C. Icahn have each separately submitted preliminary takeover proposal for Dell, the embattled computer maker.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two rival bids for Dell Inc. have emerged, threatening to complicate or change — or upend — an effort to take the embattled computer maker private in a $24 billion deal under the leadership of Michael S. Dell.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: F.C.C. Shift May Thwart a Murdoch Media Deal
articles.snippet: News Corporation wants the F.C.C. to waive a rule that would prevent it from acquiring The Los Angeles Times, but a regulator’s exit may delay further action.
articles.abstract: News Corporation wants the F.C.C. to waive a rule that would prevent it from acquiring The Los Angeles Times, but a regulator’s exit may delay further action.
articles.lead_paragraph: In weighing a bid for The Los Angeles Times, Rupert Murdoch finds himself in a familiar role: waiting for rule changes from the government. With the resignation last week of Julius Genachowski, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, he may have to wait a little longer.

articles.headline: Naughty in Name Only
articles.snippet: Sophia Amoruso turned an eBay store selling vintage finds into Nasty Gal, an online fashion retailer with nearly $100 million in annual sales.
articles.abstract: Sophia Amoruso turned an eBay store selling vintage finds into Nasty Gal, an online fashion retailer with nearly $100 million in annual sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If ever there were a Cinderella of tech, Sophia Amoruso might be it.

articles.headline: NBC Risks Its Late-Night Dominance With a ‘Tonight’ Gamble
articles.snippet: Jay Leno is still the ratings king of late-night television, but his expected replacement, Jimmy Fallon, has Internet skills and cross-generational appeal.
articles.abstract: Jay Leno is still the ratings king of late-night television, but his expected replacement, Jimmy Fallon, has Internet skills and cross-generational appeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Green Bay Packers had a long, successful run with Brett Favre until they decided in 2008 that it was time to give the quarterback job to a rising talent — Aaron Rodgers — even though the future Hall of Famer was still winning games. Now NBC is following the same script in another hugely competitive arena: late-night television.

articles.headline: Arms Airlift to Syria Rebels Expands, With Aid From C.I.A.
articles.snippet: Military help for Syria’s opposition from Arab states and Turkey has grown in recent months, and the C.I.A.’s role has indicated an American willingness to help support lethal aid.
articles.abstract: Military help for Syria’s opposition from Arab states and Turkey has grown in recent months, and the C.I.A.’s role has indicated an American willingness to help support lethal aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: With help from the C.I.A., Arab governments and Turkey have sharply increased their military aid to Syria’s opposition fighters in recent months, expanding a secret airlift of arms and equipment for the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad, according to air traffic data, interviews with officials in several countries and the accounts of rebel commanders.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Luring Young Web Warriors Is Priority. It’s Also a Game.
articles.snippet: Taking a page from China, the United States is scouring high schools for hackers, finding recruits with contests that aim to get them excited about cyberdefense.
articles.abstract: Taking a page from China, the United States is scouring high schools for hackers, finding recruits with contests that aim to get them excited about cyberdefense.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the eighth grade, Arlan Jaska figured out how to write a simple script that could switch his keyboard’s Caps Lock key on and off 6,000 times a minute. When friends weren’t looking, he slipped his program onto their computers. It was all fun and games until the program spread to his middle school.

articles.headline: Anthony Lewis, Supreme Court Reporter Who Brought Law to Life, Dies at 85
articles.snippet: Mr. Lewis, a former reporter and columnist for The Times, won two Pulitzer Prizes and altered legal journalism with his authoritative and accessible prose.
articles.abstract: Mr. Lewis, a former reporter and columnist for The Times, won two Pulitzer Prizes and altered legal journalism with his authoritative and accessible prose.
articles.lead_paragraph: Anthony Lewis, a former New York Times reporter and columnist whose work won two Pulitzer Prizes and transformed American legal journalism, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85.

articles.headline: Companies Get Strict on Health of Workers
articles.snippet: A survey found that employers are using both rewards and penalties in an effort to lower their health costs.
articles.abstract: A survey found that employers are using both rewards and penalties in an effort to lower their health costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Employers are increasingly trying to lower health care costs by using incentives to persuade workers to make better lifestyle choices, a new survey shows, but what remains less clear is whether a reward is better than a punishment — or whether the programs work at all.
